docs.lead_paragraph: Most new mothers begin the practice after birth, but quit well short of a year, federal researchers find.

headline.seo: Fewer Than Half of Babies are Breast-Fed at 6 Months, Data Shows
headline.main: Childbirth: Breast-Feeding Ends by 6 Months for Many
headline.print_headline: CHILDBIRTH: Breast-Feeding Ends by 6 Months for Many

docs.snippet: Most new mothers begin the practice after birth, but quit well short of a year, federal researchers find.

docs.lead_paragraph: Power plays! Panic attacks! Emergency trust-and-estates work! A stealth pregnancy! Secret Playboy Club escapades! Who said "As the World Turns" was over? Thick with story, Sunday night's episode of "Mad Men" took a sharp turn from the more contemplative and analytic mood of the previous weeks and geared up for the final hours of the season. | See ArtsBeat for the complete post, spoilers and all.

headline.main: 'Mad Men' Recap: Less Mood, More Plot

docs.abstract: Last night's episode of 'Mad Men' ramped up the plot points.
docs.snippet: Last night's episode of 'Mad Men' ramped up the plot points.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the centuries, most cultures have believed - and then dismissed the belief - that what happens to you in the nine months before you are born can affect everything that you become in life.
docs.abstract: Scientists are finding that what happens around you in the womb can affect you for the rest of your life.
docs.snippet: Scientists are finding that what happens around you in the womb can affect you for the rest of your life.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before we get down to the business of dissecting Sunday night's bulging-with-plot-points episode of "Mad Men,'' an announcement: Lynn Shelton, the director of the episode and of the film "Humpday," will be answering a smattering of reader questions. Post them here, in the comments section, and she will answer what she can later in the day. Lynn: Thanks and welcome!

headline.main: 'Mad Men' Watch: Power Plays and Panic Attacks

docs.abstract: The latest episode took a sharp turn from the more contemplative and analytic mood of the previous weeks and geared up for the final hours of the season.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Oh, God, doctor, I was hoping it was cancer.'' Those words so affected Dr. William Harrison that for years, he said, he could not repeat them. They made him break down in tears.

headline.main: William Harrison, 75, Dies; Defended Abortion Rights

docs.abstract: William Harrison, doctor who defended abortion rights, dies at age 75; photo (M)
docs.snippet: ''Oh, God, doctor, I was hoping it was cancer.''     Those words so affected Dr. William Harrison that for years, he said,  he could not repeat them. They made him break down in tears.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Harrison, who was the only abortion provider in northwest Arkansas, owned the Fayetteville Women’s Clinic, a frequent target of protests and attacks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Home deliveries using midwives are increasing in Illinois, despite the fact that many of them are illegal. But the law may be about to change.
